text:
What would be the likely fallout if I backed £20@1000, layed £20@1000, then the back gets voided, the runner wins, and I lose £20k though my account only contains £1k in it.

Has this ever happened? I wouldn't be keen on being forced to pay the £19k due to the poor cancellation. But then am not sure how I'd continue betting

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text:
So, race starts, Betfair fail to turn inplay for say 20 seconds. You back inside that first 20 seconds when race was running but not in the inplay market state. Then they turn inplay late, you lay using implied winnings. Then when they correct the carnage and void all bets placed while the race was off (but market was not) you are left with large red?
I'm trying to get me head around the mechanics of it - is that basically how it works?

That's absolutely savage. Surely there should be something in the settlement rules that makes that not possible?

That's absolutely savage. Surely there should be something in the settlement rules that makes that not possible?

text: I don't know the details. And I didn't take a loss as I got lucky. But for one reason or another I did have a large lay exposure due that funny race a couple of weeks ago and it's made me a bit scared.

elements.text: I don't know the details. And I didn't take a loss as I got lucky. But for one reason or another I did have a large lay exposure due that funny race a couple of weeks ago and it's made me a bit scared.

text:
I'd say that they should void anything that is later matched using implied winnings from a legitimately voided bet. Otherwise this could seriously f*** someone over.

If I were in your shoes I would investigate the details - particularly if you are worried about it. Worth putting in the effort to see exactly how you ended up in that undesirable position.

text:
Bets aren't paired so choosing which other bets should be void or not isn't straightforward, might be hundreds of them or even across two or more markets, and the consequences for the people on the other side of the bet are an issue too. 

The only way to solve this without annoying one person or another would be to void the whole market.

elements.text:
Bets aren't paired so choosing which other bets should be void or not isn't straightforward, might be hundreds of them or even across two or more markets, and the consequences for the people on the other side of the bet are an issue too. 

The only way to solve this without annoying one person or another would be to void the whole market.

text: This should not happen, I can't remember any Mops procedure that voided a time window in the past. Generally you void forwards from a point in time to Now or to the end of the event. In the case of voiding forwards to Now when the market unsuspends your inflight bet that is offsetting a now voided bet will fail expo.

elements.text: This should not happen, I can't remember any Mops procedure that voided a time window in the past. Generally you void forwards from a point in time to Now or to the end of the event. In the case of voiding forwards to Now when the market unsuspends your inflight bet that is offsetting a now voided bet will fail expo.

text: If you find evidence of it happening publish here and tell BF so Mops understand they must not do it.

elements.text: If you find evidence of it happening publish here and tell BF so Mops understand they must not do it.

text: Problems like R4 the wrong horse and unsuspending would usually be fixed by voiding bets that occurred in the false future then undoing and redoing R4. But the general principle of rolling back a market to a previous state then voiding out the false future should always be applied.

elements.text: Problems like R4 the wrong horse and unsuspending would usually be fixed by voiding bets that occurred in the false future then undoing and redoing R4. But the general principle of rolling back a market to a previous state then voiding out the false future should always be applied.

text: Correct me if I'm wrong but where a market has gone into an in-running status late, I thought they void bets after the actual start, but then still had the in running market?  Effectively treating them as two distinct markets even though many people 'trade' through the off as if it were one market.

elements.text: Correct me if I'm wrong but where a market has gone into an in-running status late, I thought they void bets after the actual start, but then still had the in running market?  Effectively treating them as two distinct markets even though many people 'trade' through the off as if it were one market.

text: I think it was supposed to void from actual start to now.

elements.text: I think it was supposed to void from actual start to now.

text: ... but I might be thinking of late bets being void on dogs where there's no ir. Late (after the start) bets on horses I'm now not sure about. :thinking_face:

elements.text: ... but I might be thinking of late bets being void on dogs where there's no ir. Late (after the start) bets on horses I'm now not sure about.

text: Anyway the principle was always to void out false futures to avoid all these problems with expo, so if it is really happening we need to tell BF.
